subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 with bea 9.2 workshop
msgSnippet: ... I think the difficulty here comes from the fact that in JUnit, test classes and test suites are hard to tell apart.  If you look at a class, it s a test
messageBody:
On 8/15/06, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@...> wrote:

> This ain't code, but maybe it'll help. Bear in mind I'm handcuffed by my
> bias towards JUnit 3.
>
> @BeforeClass makes a set up method run before running all the tests in
> that test case class (any class with at least one @Test in it).
>
> @BeforeSuite would make a set up method run before running all the tests
> in an arbitrary JUnit 3-style test suite, which might be composed of
> tests from multiple classes.


I think the difficulty here comes from the fact that in JUnit, test classes
and test suites are hard to tell apart. If you look at a class, it's a
"test suite" if has a suite() method and a "test class" otherwise. In
practice, I've always found that this blending made it hard for me to
pinpoint a specific test or series of tests that I want to investigate and
either run in isolation of the others or eliminate temporarily from the run.

From that perspective, I can understand why David says that "@BeforeClass"
is good enough and there is no need for @BeforeSuite, since @BeforeClass can
play either role depending on whether the class it applies to has a suite()
or not.

I still think that this is suboptimal, since you will radically change the
way your test is configured if you remove your suite() method, and suddenly,
a lot of before/after methods will no longer be called...
